Abstract: The advent of additive manufacturing has revolutionized the design and fabrication of soft robots, offering unprecedented flexibility and customization. This paper explores the integration of soft actuators and sensors within robotic systems, enabled by advanced 3D and 4D printing technologies. By leveraging the unique capabilities of additive manufacturing, researchers can create complex, multi-material structures that mimic biological systems, enhancing the adaptability and functionality of soft robots. The study highlights recent advancements in material science that facilitate the development of responsive, shape-morphing components, crucial for applications in medical devices, wearable technology, and autonomous systems. Furthermore, the paper discusses the potential of 4D printing to introduce time-dependent transformations, enabling robots to adapt to dynamic environments. This research underscores the transformative impact of additive manufacturing on the field of soft robotics, paving the way for innovative solutions to complex engineering challenges.
